Parameters.Text:
Welcome back to MindTrails! Let's get started with practicing flexible thinking. 

Today, you will: answer a few questions about your anxiety, complete 3 scenarios that challenge you to come up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and wrap-up with a Quick Thinking exercise. 

Let's get started!

Thinking about the last 24 hours, how anxious have you felt? 

0 = Most calm I could imagine being. 

10 = Most anxious, panicked, or scared I could imagine being.

Please touch the sliding bar to select your response, or press 'More options...'

Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much were you able to change the way you thought about things when you wanted to feel better. 

An example might be: If you were feeling worried about an upcoming test, were you able to remind yourself that you studied a lot and were prepared? 

0 = Not at all - I wasn't able to think in different ways to feel better. 

10 = Completely - I was totally able to think in different ways to feel better.

OtherChoices: I didn't want/need to change my feelings

Parameters.Text:
Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much did you try to stay away from or be less involved in situations that would make you anxious or scared? 

An example might be: If your teacher asked a question to the class and you knew the answer, do you not answer so you won't draw attention to yourself? 

0 = I tried to stay away from doing anything and everything that would make me anxious or scared. 

10 = If there was something that would make me anxious or scared, I pushed myself to do it anyway.

OtherChoices: Nothing happened that made me anxious

Parameters.Text: In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared. Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.
Please describe the situation in a few words:

Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real). Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there.
Play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds. The screen will change automatically after 20 seconds

How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task?  

0 = Absolutely no anxiety. 

10 = Totally anxious.
How vividly did you imagine the situation?
How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Items: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out badly;Very likely to turn out badly

Parameters.Text: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?

On the next screen, you will be asked to write about a possible upcoming event in your life, or something that you are worried might happen. Before pressing NEXT, please think about a situation that might happen over the next week when you will feel anxious, scared, or worried. This can be a situation that makes you anxious a lot, or something that doesn't happen a lot. 

As you think of an event, try to really see yourself in the situation. Where are you? What day of the week is it? What time is it? Who is around you? What are you doing? How do you feel?  

After you come up with your situation, please press NEXT.  

Examples could include taking a test, talking to strangers, using social media, dealing with family or friends, or whatever makes you feel anxious.
Please take a moment to write one or two sentences to describe the situation. Press next when you are ready to continue.
For the next 30 seconds, please picture yourself in this situation. When you are finished, the screen will change automatically.

Now, take the next 90 seconds to think of as many different thoughts that you could have in the situation as you can. These thoughts can be negative or positive. Be as creative as possible with all of the different thoughts you could have while you're in the situation that makes you anxious, especially thoughts that would help you feel less anxious.  

Please type each of the thoughts in the box below. You can put each thought on a new line. 

The screen will change after 90 seconds.

Great job! You predicted the future! Now, if your situation happens over the next week, you can have a lot of different thoughts come into your mind. Try to remember some of your thoughts that make you feel less anxious!
Great job practicing flexible thinking today. Remember, try to use your new flexible thinking skills before your next training session!

Sections.Name: Domains
Sections.Description: The domains listed here are some areas that may cause teens to feel anxious. Please select the one that you'd like to work on during today's training.

Parameters.Text:
Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I am a good student, and my teacher will tell my guardian that.
My teacher will say good things about me trying hard to learn.
I'm going to be in big trouble.
My guardian may ground me for doing badly in math, but I can handle it.
My teacher will tell my guardian how I'm doing in the class, and I'll be OK with that.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm glad my guardian cares enough to go talk to my teacher.
I feel calm knowing that my guardian will love me no matter what my grade is.
I'm worried about what my teacher will say to my guardian.
I feel anxious thinking about the conversation, but I can focus on my homework until my guardian gets home.
I'm uneasy right now, but this feeling won't last forever.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Press enter after each feeling to write a new one on each line.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I won't hide in my room when my guardian gets home.
I'll ask my teacher how to bring up my grade.
I'll skip math tomorrow.
I want to avoid talking to my guardian, but know it's better to get it out of the way when they get home.
I don't want to ask my teacher for help, but I know that if I do, that'll be best in the long run.

Parameters.Text:
During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You're working on your math homework with a few friends and get stuck on a problem. Your friend suggests that you find the answer online, but that's considered cheating on the assignment.

You're working on your math homework with a few friends and get stuck on a problem. Your friend suggests that you find the answer online, but that's considered cheating on the assignment. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I want to do this homework without cheating.
If I cheat, I actually won't learn the material for the test.
My friends are going to laugh at me for saying I don't want to cheat.
I hate homework, but at least it will be over soon.
My friends will make fun of me for saying I don't want to cheat, but I know I'll feel worse if I do look up the answers online.

Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

You're working on your math homework with a few friends and get stuck on a problem. Your friend suggests that you find the answer online, but that's considered cheating on the assignment. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'll be relieved when this homework is done.
I'm happier doing homework with my friends than when I'm alone.
I'm kind of frustrated that my friend say we should just cheat.
I'm anxious that my friends will make fun of me, but if they do, I can handle it.
I'm worried about my grade on the homework, but I know I'm trying my best.

You're working on your math homework with a few friends and get stuck on a problem. Your friend suggests that you find the answer online, but that's considered cheating on the assignment. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I decide that I won't cheat on this homework.
I encourage my friends to try a little longer to work on this problem.
I cheat to feel cool in front of my friends.
I kind of want to cheat so that my friends don't judge me, but I decide not to.
I feel myself wanting to cheat, but know that I really value being honest and not cheating.

Parameters.Text:
You're working on your math homework with a few friends and get stuck on a problem. Your friend suggests that you find the answer online, but that's considered cheating on the assignment. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Way to go! Now you just have one training exercise left. You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I think about how it has nothing to do with me.
I think about doing something nice for them.
I ask myself if I did something wrong.
I think I am the reason that they are fighting, but remind myself that I'm probably not the real reason.
I wonder if they're arguing over my grades, but then remember that it isn't my fault if they're not getting along.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm glad I am able to remove myself from the situation.
I feel confident that this will blow over fairly quickly.
I'm angry that they're always arguing.
I'm sad that they're arguing a lot, but know that I'm not the reason for it.
I feel anxious thinking about my parents not getting along, but remember that I can't do anything about it.

Parameters.Text:

If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling.

Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I walk away.
I go do my homework.
I yell at them to answer my question.
I give them some space and let my sad feelings pass.
I want to storm off, but walk away calmly.

Parameters.Text:

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidentally drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidentally drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I'm sure this has happened to other people.
I think about how I will help clean this up.
I think I must be the most clumsy person on the planet.
My parents might be embarrassed by me, but I know that it really isn't a big deal.
I think the waitress will be annoyed, but think about how this moment will pass.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm confident that the waitress will accept my apology.
I'm happy to be eating with my family.
I'm embarrassed that I drew attention to myself.
I'm annoyed at myself, but know that people will forget about the broken glass.
I feel guilty about having broken a glass, but know that I didn't do it on purpose.

Parameters.Text:

You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidentally drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I ask if I can help clean up.
I apologize to the wait staff and thank them for their help.
I run to the bathroom so I don't have to talk to the waiter.
I want to cry, but take a deep breath and remind myself that this happens.
I want to leave the restaurant, but stay and have a good time.

Parameters.Text:
You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidentally drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You are invited to a Halloween party and you will only know a couple of people there. You decide to wear a really elaborate costume. When you arrive, everyone looks at you.

You are invited to a Halloween party and you will only know a couple of people there. You decide to wear a really elaborate costume. When you arrive, everyone looks at you. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: This is the best costume I've ever worn.
I'm enjoying wearing this.
The other kids are judging me for wearing this costume.
I really stand out, but I think that's OK tonight.
I think that I made a huge mistake by wearing this, but realize that it's OK to wear what I want.

You are invited to a Halloween party and you will only know a couple of people there. You decide to wear a really elaborate costume. When you arrive, everyone looks at you. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm excited to show off this costume.
I'm proud of myself for wearing something that I love.
I feel really awkward while everyone stares at me.
I'm really anxious, but this feeling will pass.
I'm worried that others are making fun of me, but if they are, that's their fault for judging me.

You are invited to a Halloween party and you will only know a couple of people there. You decide to wear a really elaborate costume. When you arrive, everyone looks at you. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I walk up to some friends and start a conversation.
I'll post a picture of myself in this costume because I look great.
I'll leave the party immediately.
I want to change into something else, but decide to wear what I came in.
I want to throw this costume away and never think of tonight again, but then remember that my friend complimented me earlier on it.

Parameters.Text:
You are invited to a Halloween party and you will only know a couple of people there. You decide to wear a really elaborate costume. When you arrive, everyone looks at you. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I think everything is turned off.
I think about how I noticed during the first check everything was turned off.
I think I missed something that may have been left on.
I think I may be responsible for a disaster, but realize I am overthinking.
Even though I didn't get to fully check a second time before we all left, I'm pretty sure everything is off.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I feel confident everything was shut off.
I feel excited about the trip.
I'm worried that an appliance was left on.
I feel scared that I missed something, and then gently focus on what's going on in the car.
I feel guilty about not fully checking everything, but remind myself that everything will probably be ok and the guilty feelings will pass.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I decide to tell my parents I did not get to do a thorough second check.
I focus on what's going on in the car.
I think about all of the horrible things that could happen in the house.
I want to ask to go back to the house to check everything, but know that will make my anxiety worse in the future.
I want to cry thinking about how anxious I feel, but know that my anxiety will eventually go away.

Parameters.Text:

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.

Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You have to give a presentation in your international language class today. When you stand up in front of the class, you feel your cheeks get hot and your hands start to tremble.

You have to give a presentation in your international language class today. When you stand up in front of the class, you feel your cheeks get hot and your hands start to tremble.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: These feelings are normal and they'll go away soon.
Even if I'm a little shaky, I've prepared for this presentation.
I think everyone will notice my red cheeks.
It's possible that I'll completely forget what I was going to say, but I decide to get started and do my best.
I don't like how my cheeks feel, but I can tolerate it and will try my best.

Parameters.Text:

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

You have to give a presentation in your international language class today. When you stand up in front of the class, you feel your cheeks get hot and your hands start to tremble.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm excited to do my presentation.
I'm curious how I'll do on the presentation.
I'm terrified that I'm going to stop breathing part-way through the presentation.
I'm embarrassed that my cheeks feel hot, but I doubt anyone will actually notice.
I'm worried that I'm going to have a panic attack, but remind myself that it's normal to feel a little anxious while presenting.

You have to give a presentation in your international language class today. When you stand up in front of the class, you feel your cheeks get hot and your hands start to tremble.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I begin my presentation with a good opening line.
I hold a confident posture.
I take a step outside of the room, and decide not to come back.
I want to excuse myself, but decide to take a sip of water and carry on.
I feel the urge to cover my face, but realize that no one probably cares if my cheeks are red.

Parameters.Text:

Excellent work! Now you'll do a Quick Thinking exercise and then you'll be done for today.

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I think everything is turned off.
I think about how I noticed during the first check everything was turned off.
I think I missed something that may have been left on.
I think I may be responsible for a disaster, but realize I am overthinking.
Even though I didn't get to fully check a second time before we all left, I'm pretty sure everything is off.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I feel confident everything was shut off.
I feel excited about the trip.
I'm worried that an appliance was left on.
I feel scared that I missed something, and then gently focus on what's going on in the car.
I feel guilty about not fully checking everything, but remind myself that everything will probably be ok and the guilty feelings will pass.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I decide to tell my parents I did not get to do a thorough second check.
I focus on what's going on in the car.
I think about all of the horrible things that could happen in the house.
I want to ask to go back to the house to check everything, but know that will make my anxiety worse in the future.
I want to cry thinking about how anxious I feel, but know that my anxiety will eventually go away.

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You are babysitting a younger kid in your neighborhood and you're watching TV while they sleep. It's dark outside and you suddenly hear noises against the window.

You are babysitting a younger kid in your neighborhood and you're watching TV while they sleep. It's dark outside and you suddenly hear noises against the window. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I think it must be the wind.
I think about how there are lots of animals outside at this time.
I think about how someone could be trying to break in.
Even though my brain automatically goes to the worst case scenario, I remind myself that I'm probably safe.
I notice that I'm assuming the worst is going to happen, and remember that everything will actually be OK.

I'm tired and am looking forward to going to bed.
I feel scared that I don't know what made that noise.

I'm worried about what's outside, but remind myself that it was probably the wind.

Way to go! Now you just have one training exercise left. You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.

You post something different from what you normally post. After a couple of hours, you only have about half the number of likes on your post compared to what you normally have.

I am impressed with my post.
I think everyone is tired of my posts.
I think people think it's a dumb post, but decide not to give that a second thought.
I think everyone thought that post was boring, but I can sit with that.

On the next screen, you'll see a situation that might make someone nervous, worried, scared, or anxious. Here's an example:

You're out with friends and receive this message from your parent saying, "You need to come home right now."

In the text box, please write as many different thoughts that might come to your mind in that moment. You can add each thought to a new line. You'll have 60 seconds to do this. 

For this example, you might write: 
What did I do wrong? 
 My parent has something really important to tell me. 
 I'm really tired, so I'm glad to be going home. 

The screen will automatically change after 60 seconds.

Imagine yourself in the following situation. Please write as many different thoughts that might come to mind in that moment. You have 60 seconds. You can press "enter" or "return" on your keyboard between thoughts. 

You ask a new student at your school for their name on social media, and they don't respond.
Great job practicing flexible thinking today. Remember, try to use your new flexible thinking skills before your next training session!
